"It is something that I‚Äôd like you to look at and see if we can resolve as it really is going to be a key factor as we head into the farm bill."

"We very much enjoy working with you, but this lack of responsiveness has been disappointing. And it is not only for me, but members on our side of the aisle, and a lot of this is actually inquiries that are bipartisan."
"We really depend on USDA as we write this farm bill, because we need to understand how the policies we are considering would be implemented."

"I‚Äôm growing increasingly concerned about USDA‚Äôs ability to provide timely responses, however. Just yesterday, I received a response to a letter I wrote to you in October, which was not entirely responsive."

"Senator Stabenow and I are proud of the accomplishments we made in the last Congress and, in every instance where we‚Äôve been successful, we‚Äôve experienced constructive and timely technical feedback from USDA."
"Before I close, I would like to mention one final issue: the importance of a productive, working relationship between Congress and the technical experts at USDA as we develop the farm bill."
"All farms are valuable. This farm bill will not neglect the small nor punish the large."

"Farm programs have not kept pace with the needs of modern agriculture & are not responsive in the face of pandemics or geopolitical pressures. The current safety net does not reflect the current levels of risk taken on each year by those that provide the food, fiber & fuel."

"And in order to pay that back, you must contend with the weather, the markets, the economy and global politics. These are many of the reasons why when I meet with my farmers, they all tell me that the 'safety net' is badly frayed and needs to be reinforced."

"The capital cost of getting into agriculture is enormous and farmers are going to have to rely more heavily on credit this year. How many other jobs require that you take out a loan the size of a mortgage, or larger, each year?"
"Farm production costs have increased 28%, or nearly $90 billion."

"Farm debt is over half-a-trillion at $535 billion. Input costs are still high; supply chains are easing but remain tight; interest rates have rapidly increased and, by percentage, represent the largest cost increase our producers will face this year."

Yet, for nearly 6 decades these heroic women were denied the recognition & benefits they had earned through their service.

On behalf of a grateful nation, I believe it's time we honored these women with the highest civilian award bestowed by Congress, a Congressional Gold Medal.

When our allies and armed forces were in desperate need of modern communication capabilities during WWI, the Hello Girls answered the call to defend freedom abroad, making them the first women to be officially deployed to a combat zone by the U.S. military in American history.

As we celebrate Women‚Äôs History Month & the remarkable contributions of women, I‚Äôm proud to introduce legislation to give the Congressional Gold Medal to the Hello Girls‚Äîa group of 220+ women that were instrumental in allied victory in WWI.

I'm proud we're continuing our bipartisan push to recognize these incredible women, their service to the nation, and their subsequent 60-year fight for equal treatment as veterans. Let's get this done. (6/6)

The Hello Girls risked their lives to protect our nation and led critical efforts that helped our allied forces win the war. They blazed a new path for women on the front lines, and the Congressional Gold Medal will honor their service and fight for recognition as veterans. (5/6)

One of these women was Merle Egan Anderson of Montana. Merle led the effort to get the Hello Girls the recognition they deserved, petitioning Congress more than 50 times to acknowledge their veteran status.

And in 1977, Congress finally got things right and did. (4/6) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FrXXbglWIAYtK71.jpg

They served at military headquarters and commanded outposts in the field alongside the American Expeditionary Forces.

But despite their outstanding service, they were denied their veteran status and benefits when they returned home. (3/6)

The Hello Girls are the women of the U.S. Army Signal Corps‚Äîrecruited during World War I after male infantrymen struggled to connect calls quickly and communicate with their French counterparts.

These bilingual women were deployed to France and took the Army oath in 1917. (2/6)
